summary.seg: The manuscript contains Three rhetorical texts by Libanius, a pagan Greek rhetorician of the 4th century BCE, translated in Latin by Desiderius Erasmus (1466 or 1469-1536), together with the original texts in Greek copied by him. The texts are a declamation ( melete), Legatio Menelai, and two ethopoeiae, model rhetorical exercises, speeches on fictional themes, used in an educational context.

The manuscript is written by Erasmus himself (see the note on f. 1r, and Bernardinello 1979, no. 61), and is the presentation copy to Nicholas Ruistre (Nicolaus Ruterius ca. 1442-1509), bishop of Arras, as indicated by a dedication letter by Erasmus dated on 17th November 1503, and by the presence of the arms of the bishop, painted on f. 3v. Erasmus received from Ruistre 10 gold pieces for this Libanius (see Garrod 1950, p. 9). Erasmus' translations were printed afterwards, by Thomas Martens in Louvain, in 1519 (see Morgan-Panaytova 2009, p. 112).

msItem.title: Epigram (Reedijk no. 75)

msItem.title: Dedication to Nicholas Ruistre
msItem.incipit: f. 3v Reverendo in Christo patri Nicolao Ruterio
msItem.explicit: f. 11r Lovanii anno a Christo nato MDIII decimo quinto calendas Decembres
msItem.note: Ed. P.S. Allen, Opus epistolarum Desiderii Erasmi Roterdami, Oxford 1906, no. 177

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Legatio Menelai (Decl. 3 Foerster), Latin translation by Desiderius Erasmus
msItem.rubric: f. 11r Declamatio Libanii sophistae sub persona Menelai pro concione Troianorum Helenam et res repetentis, ni reddant, armis iniuriam ulturum se denunciantis. Latina facta Erasmo Desiderio interprete
msItem.incipit: f. 11v Si quidem Paris viri Troiani
msItem.finalRubric: f. 26v Finis declamationis Libanii sophistae e Graeco sermone in Latinum conversae Erasmo Desiderio canonico ordinis divi Aurelii Augustini. Qui dicitur interprete anno salutis millesimo quingentesimo tercio mense novembre
msItem.note: Ed. Libanius. Aliquot declamatiunculae Graecae, eademque Latinae, per Desiderium Erasmum Roterodamum, Lovanii 1519

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Ethopoeiae (Progymn. 11.1 Foerster), Latin translation by Desiderius Erasmus
msItem.rubric: f. 27r Τίνας ἂν εἴποι λόγους Μήδεια μέλλουσα ἀποσφάττειν τοὺς ἑαυτῆς παῖδας. Declamatio
msItem.incipit: f. 27r Fuit et mihi mea ars auxilio
msItem.note: Ed. Libanius. Aliquot declamatiunculae Graecae, eademque Latinae, per Desiderium Erasmum Roterodamum, Lovanii 1519

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Ethopoeiae (Progymn. 11.2 Foerster), Latin translation by Desiderius Erasmus
msItem.rubric: f. 32r Quae dixerit Andromache interfecto Hectore. Declamatio
msItem.note: Ed. Libanius. Aliquot declamatiunculae Graecae, eademque Latinae, per Desiderium Erasmum Roterodamum, Lovanii 1519

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Legatio Menelai (Decl. 3 Foerster)
msItem.finalRubric: f. 49r Τοῦ Λιβανίου σοφιστοῦ τῆς μελέτης τέλος· σὺν θεῷ ἀρχὴν ἁπάντων καὶ τέλος ποιοῦ θεόν· ἀρκεῖ τ' ἐν μεγάλοις καὶ τὸ θέλημα μόνον· ἔρρωσθε

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Ethopoeiae (Progymn. 11.1 Foerster)
msItem.rubric: f. 50r Quae dixerit Medaea suos mactatura filios. Declamatio.
msItem.incipit: f. 50r Εἶχον ἄρα καὶ αὐτὴ βοήθειαν

msItem.author: Libanius
msItem.title: Ethopoeiae (Progymn. 11.2 Foerster)
msItem.rubric: f. 54v Τίνας ἂν εἴποι λόγους Ἀνδρομάχη ἀναιρεθέντος Ἕκτορος· μελέτη
msItem.incipit: f. 54v Ἥκει δὴ πρὸς ἔργον ὁ φόβος
msItem.explicit: f. 56v μίγνυσθαι τῷ τὸν Ἕκτορα ἀπεκτονότι.

support.material:
ff. [iii]-[vi], 1-2, 5-63 Western paper, folded in quarto.
Watermarks:
ff. [iii]-[vi], 1-2, 7-8, 58-63 Assembled letters (unclear), surmounted by a crown and a clover ( ca. 40 25 ) in the gutter, no parallels found in the main repertoires.
ff. 5-6, 9-57 Hand surmounted by a four-leaf clover (type Briquet Main , au naturel, face interne) ( ca. 50 15 ) , comparable to the types Briquet Main 11421, 11423, 11424, 11425, which are dated in 1483, 1496, 1502-1508, 1507.
ff. [i]-[ii], [vii]-[viii] Western paper, folded in folio, no watermarks (later endleaves associated with the binding).

foliation.p: Modern foliation in pencil, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin right, from 1 to 63: [i]-[vi] + 1-63 + [vii]-[viii].

collation.p: The manuscript consists mainly of quaternions. Quire 2 is a bifolium of parchment. The quires have been sewn tightly and are not numbered, therefore the collation has been reconstructed on the basis of the watermark positions. Quire 9 is a quaternion missing the last leaf (with no loss of text).

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in good condition. Two paper strips have been pasted on the external margins of ff. [iii] and 2, which were damaged.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column of 14-15 lines (15 in the Greek part).
130-140 80

handNote.p: ff. 34v-49r, 50r-56v Hand A: the texts have been written by Erasmus, Desiderius, -1536 Desiderius Erasmus (Bernardinello 1979, no. 61; see also Garrod 1950, p. 10), in a minuscule script slanting to the right, characterized by the presence of ornamental hooks at the end of uprights. The text is written in a brown ink. Titles and some initials are written in red. For the titles, the scribe used a majuscule script.
The Latin texts on ff. 2v, 3v-34v have been also written by Erasmus.

decoDesc.decoNote: On f. 3v, in the centre of the leaf, with the text written around it, is painted a shield, coloured in blue, with trompe l'oeuil arms of Nicholas Ruistre, on a crozier, surmounted by a scroll with the motto Aequo animo; three mice run on the left edge of the shield.

On f. 4r there is a brown and gold acanthus initial on a square ground coloured in pink and grey. On f. 11v there is a zoomorphic initial (dragon) painted in blue, gold and brown, on a square ground coloured in pink. On f. 35r there is a golden and brown initial on a square ground coloured in blue.
The text ends in form of a cross on ff. 49r and 56v; in the form of a chalice on ff. 31v, 54r.

additions.p: On the left pastedown is written, in pencil, the shelfmark, R.9.26.
On f. [i] recto there is a note, in pencil, concerning the donation of the manuscript; a note on the same topic, in brown ink, on f. [iii] verso (see Acquisition).
On f. [iii] recto is written, in black ink, the shelfmark R.9.26.

On f. 1r there are notes by Abraham Ortelius, in brown ink, about the manuscript, its contents and history:
Declamationes tres, prima Libanii Sophistae, reliquae incerti authoris. Ab Erasmo Roterodamo Latio donatae.
Scriptus est liber manu ipsius interpretis, Domini Erasmi Roterodami nempe. Constat hoc mihi Ab. Ortelis.
. Below is written the name of Ortelius' nephew, Jacob/James Cool/Cole, Jacobi Colii Orteliani 1598
In the upper margin, left, of f. 3v is written the shelfmark, R.9.26

binding.p:
Western binding, leather cover over couched-laminate boards; blind tooling on the boards' edges. Parchment on spine, where there are a gold tooled title, Declamat. | Libanii | Etc. , and three paper labels with the shelfmark, R, 9, 26.
210 140 16
binding.condition: There are scratches on the cover.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by Desiderius Erasmus in Louvain in 1503: this date occurs at the end of the presentation letter (17 November 1503, see f. 11r), and in the final rubric of the first text (November 1503, see f. 26v). Since also the following texts were written by the same hand on the same paper, it can be assumed that they were copied in the same period.

history.provenance:
The manuscript was owned by
Le Ruistre, Nicolas, 14..-1509 Nicolas Ruistre (d. 1509) , bishop of Arras, whom the copy was dedicated. After his death in 1509, the manuscript could have returned briefly to the hands of Erasmus ( Garrod 1950, p. 9). It was later owned by the cartographer
Abraham Ortelius (1527-1598) Ortelius, Abraham, 1527-1598. , see his note on f. 1r, Constat hoc mihi Ab. Ortelis. Ortelius collected autographs by Erasmus ( Garrod 1950, p. 10). The codex, after his death in 1598, passed to his nephew Colius, Jacobus, 1563-1628 Jacobus Colius (Jacob/James Cool/Cole) , see note on f. 1r, Jacobi Colii Orteliani 1598. After Cole's death in 1628, the manuscript was given to his nephew, Abraham Bush ( Garrod 1950, p. 10).
history.acquisition:
The manuscript was donated to the Library by
Peters, Hugh, 1598-1660 Hugh Peters (1598-1660) , a preacher of Dutch origin, chaplain in England during the Civil war, and minister of the church of Salem in New England, who studied in Cambridge as member of Trinity College; see a modern note in pencil on f. [i] recto, Given by Hugh Peters 1657, and an earlier one, in brown ink, on f. [iii] verso, Me sibi vendicat Bibliotheca Collegii Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigiense ex dono Domini Hugonis Petri. A.D. 1657. On the same leaf is pasted the Trinity College bookplate.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on M. R. James, M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge, vol. 2, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1901, pp. 268-270.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
